Spain’s Geography Islands Climate And Their Roles In Tour

Spain is ranked as 52nd country in the world in terms of size. It covers an area of 505,992 square km. Mt Teide is Spain’s highest peak and the volcano that’s ranked third in the category of largest mountains in the world from its base. Its latitudes are 26° and 44°N. The longitudes are 19° and 5°E.

Spain is a highly mountainous region and also has some major rivers. The mainland especially has very many mountains and mountain chains that are ideal for skiing most especially during the winter period. The mainland has high plateaus and mountain chains. The Pyrenees are the major ranges but there are others such as Sistema Penibetico, Sierra Morena, Montes de Toledo, Sistema Central, Sistema Iberico and Cordillera Cantabrica.

Some of the peaks here are so high that they have received international recognition. Spain’s highest point is Teide which is an active volcano of 3,718 meters and is located in the Canary Islands. The most popular plateau is Meseta Central found at the heart of Spain.

Spain’s major rivers include the Guadalquivir, the Guadiana, the Duero, the Ebro and the Tagus. Spain’s largest plains are the Guadalquivir in Andalusia. These are found at the coastal region of Spain.

Spain has a lot of territorial islands some of which are not inhabited. The Mediterranean Sea hosts the Balearic Islands. The great Atlantic Ocean homes Spain’s most popular islands, the Canary Islands. The uninhabited islands are mostly in the Mediterranean Sea in the popular Strait of Gibraltar called Plazas de Soberania. Some of the islands here include Pheasant Island, Isla Perejil, Isle of Alboran Alhcemas and Chafarine islands. All these islands are a major tourist attraction contributing greatly to Spain’s economy.

Climate is yet another very important aspect of Spain. There are three climates in Spain. They are Mediterranean, Semi arid and oceanic climates. These are dependent on the specific locations within Spain and are categorized as such.

The Mediterranean climate is evidenced by warm dry summers. This type of climate dominates the peninsula. Examples of the areas that experience this type of climate in Spain include Leon, Madrid and Burgos. These places attract a lot of visitors during summer.

Semiarid climate is experienced in the Spain’s southeastern quarter. It is prevalent in Ebro and Murcia valleys. Dry seasons go beyond summer.

The oceanic climate is prevalent in the north. The climate is greatly influenced by the ocean and the diverse climates within the same region are what a number of people come to witness.

FESTIVALS IN SPAIN

There are lot festivities that are celebrated in Spain. Some are quite traditional and have been celebrated since time immemorial. These festivals are very unique and can only be seen in the land. All neighborhoods, cities, towns and regions have saints that are attributed feasts that are accorded a lot of importance. The festivals are celebrated in a religious manner every year. Some of the traditions are only celebrated in Spain.

Bull fighting is a festival widely celebrated in Spain. The frequency of this occasion that used to be of great importance to the Spanish people has greatly declined over the years. This follows the intensive works of animal activists who name the festival as oppressive to the animals. It is a major part of Spain’s history as well as the traditions that are common with the Spaniards. The sport is quite dangerous as a lot of harm can be done to either the animal or even the rider. This activity has been reduced to a few occasions in the present and anyone who wishes to witness the fights must try making an early ticket booking so as not to miss the opportunity.

Christmas festivities are common in all regions of the world. In Spain however, there are additional rituals that are involved with the festivities. There is a bonfire that is associated with Christmas in Spain. It initiates the Christmas celebrations. The celebration was initially to celebrate the shortest winter day. Spaniards jump over each other during this period symbolizing the overcoming of illness. They do not eat the Christmas dinner before midnight and the people stay awake for the rest of the night singing Christmas carols for the rest of the night so as not to waste the “goodnight” with sleep.

There are celebrations dedicated to saints that are specific to different regions. There are feasts dedicated to patron saints as well as many other traditions that are quite different from any others in the world.

Palm Sunday is also accorded a lot of attention and the celebrations in Spain are quite major. Palm Sunday sees the people go to church while the little ones are made to carry some palm leaves that are in turn blessed by the priests. Ash Wednesday is also important in the Spanish calendar. Ashes are applied as a sign of patience and to remind everyone that we are from the ashes and to ashes shall we return. Fasting marks the lent season. All this festivities are very attractive to pilgrims and generally to a number of tourists.

Island Destination in Spain

Spain’s location is very prime. It actually enjoys two major water bodies, i.e. the Atlantic and the Mediterranean. These water bodies play a major role in facilitating the sun and sand destinations. Apart from the coastlines, Spain has some island territories in both oceans. The Mediterranean has the Balearic Islands while the Atlantic homes the Canary Islands. These are all wonderful places to go on holiday.

Fondly referred to as "Mediterranean paradise", the Balearics live up to the title. The Balearic Islands has two parts. One is to the southwest while the other is northern. The north region is known as Gimnesias which is made up of Cabrera, Mallorca and Menorca. The south is called Pitiusas comprising of Ibiza and Formentera. The most popular island in this chain is Ibiza. The island is fondly called the ‘white island’. It has been a great destination from the 1960’s.

It is a one of the regions that have a nudist approach as well as has the hippie culture. It is a celebrated destination especially among the young people because of the nightlife culture. The region receives a great deal of visitors each year. The most popular features here even more than the beaches are the discotheques. These are known to operate even in the very odd hours of the day.

The Mediterranean culture is quite evident in the region. The wall paintings known as the Ses Fontelles are a major evidence. Transportation in Ibiza is not hard as there is an airport serving the region as well as many shuttle cars that operate in the region.

The Canary Islands as said earlier are located in the Atlantic sea. They were formed through volcanic activity as evidenced by the rich black sands at the beaches. The climate is sub tropical. There are other smaller islands affiliated to the canary island. The good climate makes the Canary Islands a perfect place to spend a holiday all year round.

Canary Island has a total of seven islands that are further divided in two. The two parts are Santa Cruz de Tenerife and Las Palmas provinces. These island destinations are the perfect choice for anyone who loves life and also having a good time.

Tower of Hercules Spain

Monuments form a great part of tourist attractions since they not only give the visitors the chance to learn about the history of the country but also to see the great architectural techniques. Some of the monuments in Spain are famed for their unique architectural work while some hold great historical significance. The Spanish heritage is also hidden within the monuments and they therefore remain to be a treasure.

The tower of Hercules is a national monument in Spain. It is found in La Caruna Harbor on the northwest part of Spain. This is a great example of monuments reflecting the heritage of Spain. Constructed back in the 1st century AD, it had the name Farum Brigantium. The careful preservation of this tower is what has seen it being raised to a national monument and it therefore attracts tourists from all over the world. It however underwent updating during the 18th century and it is actually currently a Roman lighthouse that is fully functional.

This beautiful tower stands at 180 feet and it has a captivating sculpture park for its surrounding. Within this park there is a cemetery that is quite old as well as rock carvings Monte dos Bicos which are from the interesting Iron Age. The Tower of Hercules not only serves as a great Roman architecture relic but also has great insights as far as maritime routes and ancient systems of navigation are concerned.

The tower offer magnificent views and it can be quite romantic. It is possible for people to get to the top area from where the beautiful views of the harbor can be enjoyed. It is one of the best monuments in Spain and one which cannot be missed by those visiting the area. It is visible from far and you will be amazed by just how strong it is even though it is quite old. The renovations and upgrading have put it in a better and stronger condition and it is clear that it will serve it lighthouse purpose for a very long time.

Spain is one of the best holiday destinations of the world. It has a little of everything among them the wonderful monuments with a different story to tell for each. It is a country offering a wonderful touring chance for every kind of traveler or holidaymaker from the different parts of the world and you can be sure to enjoy your time within the beautiful country.

The Seville Cathedral

Spain has numerous monuments that are well spread out in the many regions of the country. They are mainly cathedrals, churches, museums and other buildings which have great historical, religious or architectural value to the country. It is true to say that you will always find something interesting in every part of the country thus making your tour or holiday in these areas most enjoyable and also memorable.

Among the many attractions that you will find in Seville is the Cathedral. It is a popular monument that attracts thousands of visitors coming into Spain. It is actually a must see monument of the city and is among the largest gothic cathedrals that you will find in the world. It makes it to the list of gothic cathedrals such as San Pietro that is in Rome and the St. Paul’s cathedral that is in London.

Where the Seville Cathedral now stands, there once used to be a huge mosque but unfortunately it collapsed. It was after this collapse back in 1401 that the construction of the Seville Cathedral began. It continued for a whole century and you will find the rectangular wide shape of this cathedral interesting. It is because it was put up on the base plan of the mosque thus the unusual shape the Cathedral now has.

The Seville cathedral definitely has some areas that cannot be missed by the visitors taking the time to behold its beauty. They include the 30 chapels that are within it, the Christopher Columbus tomb that is on the southern entrance to the cathedral and also the Patio de Los Naranjos, a beautiful garden that is on cathedra’s northern side. This cathedral also has the La Giralda tower which is the most outstanding feature on it. It was put up in 1184 and it’s indeed a very unique part of the beautiful huge cathedral.

The tower stands at 70 meters and has a sebka design on the outer part while the inner part has 35 ramps and an interesting observation platform. It is a great area to enjoy the beautiful view of the city and you will find visitors here in their numbers. The Seville Cathedral is definitely one of the places that are a must visit in the city. You can enjoy a guided tour of the cathedral to ensure that you get to see everything that is unique and valuable within and without the cathedral.

The Alhambra Palace in Granada Spain

This world famous palace of Spain is among the most visited places throughout Spain and it is therefore one of the monuments in Spain that you cannot afford to miss out on. It got its name Alhambra which stands for red from the reddish brown bricks used to construct its outer walls. It is located in the most beautiful natural place in Granada with snow capped summits for its backdrop. It is near the Sierra Nevada Mountain and the Darra River making a great location for a Spanish tour or holiday.

Things to see on the palace

Just like any other monument or building in Spain, there are parts which cannot be missed while visiting the Alhambra palace. It mainly is divided into four parts including Palacios Nazaries, Alcazaba, Generalife and Palacio de Carlos. The Alcazaba which is a castle happens to be the palace’s oldest part having been put up in 13th century. The watch tower Torre de la Vela is where the panoramic view of the city can be enjoyed while Generalife is a wonderful garden of a palace.

Other features of the palace which are worth checking out on your tour include the museums de la Alhambra and the Fine Arts. They are both within Palacio de Carlos V. The Salon de Embajadores has impressive embroideries and extraordinary art making it another feature that is worth checking out. It is a bog saloon once used by the ambassadors and the kingdom. Also worth seeing are the Patio de los Leones, the Women Tower and the Old Hamman, Albacin and the Kingdom Chapel.

It is important for all visitors to know that the tickets to this beautiful palace can be very limited. This is as a result of issues to do with the conservation and therefore only a certain number is allowed to visit every day. It is important that you book your ticket a day before leaving for the site to ensure that you manage to explore the palace well. It is a popular palace that receives huge numbers of visitors and therefore to avoid the long queues, it is advisable to get the tickets in advance.

Religion And Tourism in Spain

Spain’s religion comprises of Judaism, Islam, and Catholicism. It is a country that homes some of the places that are considered as the holiest. Santiago de Compstela which is in Galicia is said to be third in holiness after Jerusalem and Vatican City.

The Way of Saint James terminus is also found in Spain. The fourth and fifth holiest places are Santo Toribio de Liebana and Caravaca de la Cruz respectively. The areas receive a lot of pilgrims every year especially around the Easter period during the last week of lent. The holy week processions are a major tourist attraction. The processions are most important in many Spanish towns.

Semana Santa or holy week traditions have made the Spanish religion recognized. Most tourists and pilgrims plan a trip for long periods of time so as to be in Spain in time for the processions. The activities within the procession differ from one town to the other while some are known to be stricter than others. The processions are most glamorous in Andalusia regions specifically Zamora, Castile, Seville and Malaga. The holy week is considered to be one of the religious holidays in Spain. Malaga and Seville hold the most interesting processions. More somber processions can be seen in Castile and Zamora.

Though the events may differ in arrangement from one location to the other, there are some common features one of which is the use of the penitential robe referred to as nazareno. This is worn by some of the people within the procession. This rope is designed in a way that it is able to keep he wearers face concealed by including a conical tipped hood. A cloak is also included in some cases. Colors are procession specific. These robes are historic by themselves. They were used during medieval period especially for penitents. In this way, people could clearly display penance while discreetly concealing their identity from the rest.

In most processions, the nazarenos bear candles as well as wooden crosses. Some may be barefoot while others may bear chains or shackles on the feet so as to show penance.

The Cartagena processions are said to have more uniqueness as well as very strict orders. In some processions, there are usually bands or even mournful singers that can be heard throughout the procession. These processions in the areas of Spain mentioned are great tourist attractions some of whom comprise of pilgrims from all over the world who come to witness this amazing event that occurs every year thus religion contributes to the tourism sector in a great way.
